newsitem.title: UK: Med oil products broadly stronger.
newsitem.headline: Med oil products broadly stronger.

text.p: Mediterranean oil products were steady to firmer on Friday.
Naphtha prices were steady with cargoes at $216/$218 cif and traders waiting for results from the Egyptian tender that closed this week for further direction.
Stronger crude continued to underpin prices but the Med was seen well balanced with most end user demand seen satisfied and cargoes heading north were believed to have homes.
Gasoline prices also edged up with a rebound in crude and a correction to Thursday's selloff, but the market was well balanced and not as volatile as northwest Europe, traders said.

Higher sulphur gas oil grades were slightly firmer in line with the NWE market and benchmark futures, with supply tightening after a Turkish tender, due to be awarded tonight, soaked up 100,000 tonnes of second half November product. Good demand was also seen elsewhere in the eastern Med.
But EU grade diesel looked under pressure with ample local supply, particularly from Algeria.
The arbitrage to Asia was now unworkable, traders said, after two cargoes recently headed out of the region to India.
Low sulphur cracked fuel oil rose, broadly on the back of stronger paper that saw a Dec trade concluded at $125 fob NWE.

A low sulphur cargo out of Port Jerome, sold yesterday at $121.50 fob NWE, changed hands on Friday at cif high quotes +3.00 basis two Italian ports. Traders said sellers were unlikely to accept below about $130 cif.

High sulphur cracked was steady around $107 fob Med with good demand offset by a Syrian 50kt cargo looking increasingly distressed. Dealers said there was talk of bringing in NWE cargoes to meet demand, but nothing was seen concluded. An M-100 was sold at cif high +$3 cif Falconnara.
